issues.title: # of instances of AttestCertsAttribute
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
> >>
> >>     A CSR MUST contain at most 1 AttestCertsAttribute. In the case where the CSR contains multiple instances of AttestAttribute representing multiple attestations, all necessary certificates MUST be contained in the same instance of AttestCertsAttribute.
> >>
> >>  
> >>
> >> Perhaps to make the wording easier, shall we change the description to “A CSR MUST only contain  exactly one AttestCertsAttribute”?
> >
> > Sounds like a good idea.
> 
> It's only a good idea if you ignore:
> 
> > [[MO]] But a CSR can also contain zero instances of AttestCertsAttribute, for example if you know that the RP already knows your public key then you have no need to transmit any certs. Alternatively, maybe there exists an Attestation format where the certs are buried inside the AttestStatement.
> > [[MO]] I could change the wording to “A CSR MUST contain 0 or 1 instances of AttestCertsAttribute” if that is clearer?
> 
> Given that you can't have less than zero instances of an attribute in a CSR, "at most one" is the same as "zero or one".   I wouldn't object to a change to zero or one, but I would to "exactly one".  If you always require exactly one, you will most likely be duplicating information that's available in the body of the actual attestation statement included in the AttestAttribute (cf Webauthn attestation formats).
> 
> Mike

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
I was coming here to open the same issue.

Tasks:
1. Re-word "at most one" to "zero or one".
2. Add text making it clear that the AttestCertsAttribute is optional and SHOULD be omitted if there are no certs to be carried, for example if the attestation key is already known to the verifier, or if the attestation statement format being carried already includes the cert chain, as is the case with WebAuthn -- see [WebAuthn-2 s. 8.2](https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#sctn-packed-attestation).

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: This has been addressed.

issues.title: Re-use of RATS’s Conceptual Messages Wrapper (CMW)
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
Remark from Thomas:

> It looks very much like RATS’s CMW [1], except CMW builds on media types rather than OIDs to provide the typing information (and therefore does not need bootstrapping and maintenance of yet another IANA registry).
>  
> IMO it’d be better if we could converge on one only encap format.  Not only to avoid unnecessary duplication, but also because from the point of view of the RA/CA an AttestStatement is just a byte string that needs to be forwarded to their trusted attestation Verifier.  The RA/CA does not need to know which type of attestation statement it’s dealing with, as long as it knows that it’s a blob that the attestation Verifier will make sense of.
> 
> [1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ftbs-rats-msg-wrap-03#section-3.1


Proposal from Russ:
> 
> PKIXAttestIdentifier ::= CHOICE {
>    coap-content-format INTEGER (0..65535),
>    media-type IA5String }
> 
> CMOptions ::= ENUMERATED {
>    reference-values,
>    endorsements,
>    evidence,
>    attestation-results }
> 
>   PKIX-ATTESTATION ::= CLASS {
>       &id  PKIXAttestIdentifier UNIQUE,
>       &AttestType,
>       &cm CMOptions OPTIONAL
>   } WITH SYNTAX {
>       TYPE &AttestType IDENTIFIED BY &id [FOR &cm]
>   }
> 
>   PKIXAttestation{PKIX-ATTESTATION:PKIXAttestSet} ::= SEQUENCE {
>       attestID      PKIX-ATTESTATION.&id({PKIXAttestSet}),
>       attestType    CMOptions OPTIONAL,
>       attestValue   PKIX-ATTESTATION.&AttestType({PKIXAttestSet}{@attestID})
>   }
> 
> PKIXAttestSet PKIX-ATTESTATION ::= { ... }
> 

Suggestion from Thomas:

> I'd be more radical and just put the CMW as-is into an OCTET STRING.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
We should respond to this on-list.
The core question here is whether LAMPS / CSR should be specifying encodings other than ASN.1.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> The core question here is whether LAMPS / CSR should be specifying encodings other than ASN.1.

LAMPS shouldn't specify core attestation formats, they already exist and are specified by other SDOs (e.g., FIDO, TCG, W3C) and IETF groups (e.g,. RATS).

The suggestion of using CMW (wrapped in a ASN.1 OCTET STRING) fully decouples attestation formats from the CSR format, making the latter scalable.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> We should respond to this on-list. The core question here is whether LAMPS / CSR should be specifying encodings other than ASN.1.

What is the rationale for redefining something that is already defined but doesn't use ASN.1 as the data definition language?

I makes sense to consider the constraints of the environments that are creating the CSR structures and their capabilities. HSMs that already support ASN.1/DER likely will object to some other encoding (e.g., CBOR), but environments that are already capable of CBOR may object to ASN.1/DER etc. Given there are use cases for CSRs originating from various environments such as DICE Protection Environment (DPE), SPDM Responders, and embedded uControllers (but not HSMs). Given there can be layers of compute that may issue a CSR, the CSR draft should be flexible toward accommodating industry evolution and trends rather than serve to constrain or limit such evolution.

issues.title: Freshness "out-of-scope" vs "not required"
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
Since the document discusses it, it is by definition, in-scope.

Perhaps change the paragraph to say "is not required", or "is left up to the discretion of protocol designers and implementors" or something similar.

The whole paragraph about freshness probably needs a re-write for consistency since it currently reads like it was written by two authors (which it was).

comments.author: carl-wallace
comments.body: I don't think "not required" is what you want here but your second option seems fine. Maybe something like "while this specification does not impose any freshness requirements, an attestation format or certificate management protocol may impose freshness requirements".

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
MSJ:
> the freshness is less relevant, because we expect the protection of the key will never get worse (except for a compromise, which is not our problem today).

We could add wording to the security consideration to this effect -- ie that since we are asserting immutable / non-roll-backable properties of the private key's storage, freshness is less relevant.

That said, this feels like it's getting pretty deep into the semantics of a key attestation / platform attestation; which we are trying to avoid making assumptions about in this transport draft.

issues.title: ATTRIBUTE or EXTENSION to satisfy CRMF
issues.author: ounsworth

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Specify in text:

> This Extension is intended only for use within CRMF CSRs and is NOT RECOMMENDED for use within X.509 certificates because publishing evidence carries privacy implications which are not considered in this document. See {{security-considerations}} for more discussion.

> # Security Considerations
> ## Publishing evidence in an X.509 extension
> This document specifies how to carry evidence in a PKCS#10 or CRMF Certificate Signing Request (CSR), but it is intentionally NOT RECOMMENDED for a CA to re-use that CRMF extension to publish the evidence in the resulting X.509 certificate. The reason for this is that the evidence might contain detailed information about hardware and patch levels of the device on which the private key resides. Certificates are considered public information. The certificate requester has consented to sharing this detailed device information with the CA but might not consent to having them published.
> These privacy considerations are beyond the scope of this document and may require additional signaling mechanisms in the CSR to prevent unintended publication of sensitive information, so we leave it as "NOT RECOMMENDED".

issues.title: Optimizing the EvidenceBundle Structure
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
The current draft (version -02) defines the EvidenceBundle as follws:

> 
>    EvidenceBundle ::= SEQUENCE
>    {
>      evidence  SEQUENCE OF EvidenceStatement,
>      certs SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives OPTIONAL
>    }
> 

The idea is that Evidence can be sent with optionally with a certificate chain. In complex scenarios (such as Composite Devices) the sequence construct allows multiple Evidence payloads to be conveyed in a CSR. In such a situation it is possible to convey a certificate chain with each Evidence payload.

The payload construction would be something like:

               Evidence1
               cert1
               Evidence2
               cert2

We have also envisioned the case where the certificate chain is the same for all Evidence payloads. In such a case, it is possible to accomplish a performance optimization by only send one cert chain. Here is the payload construction:

               Evidence1
               Evidence2
               cert

If the certificate chains differ, then this optimization is not possible.

Mike StJohns brought up a scenario where the current design of the EvidenceBundle is limiting. In his scenario multiple Evidence payloads are sent and their certificate chain only differents by the end entity certificate. In the current design an optimization would not be possible.

Question: Should we allow this optimization? If so, how should we best design it?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
> Mike StJohns brought up a scenario where the current design of the EvidenceBundle is limiting. In his scenario multiple Evidence payloads are sent and their certificate chain only differents by the end entity certificate. In the current design an optimization would not be possible.

I disagree; in the current design you can do:

~~~
[Evidence1, Evidence2]
[Cert1, Cert2, [rest of common cert chain] ]
~~~

We have been clear that this is a bag of certs, not a chain, so this is perfectly allowed.
Where MSJ might have a point is if the Verifier cannot handle this and needs to be given

~~~
Evidence1
[Cert1, [rest of common cert chain] ]
~~~

then either the RP needs semantic knowledge of the payload so that it can reconstruct, or the Attester needs to use multiple EvidenceBundles and duplicate certs. This is not ideal for those usecases, but I don't think it's worth changing the design to accommodate it.

@hannestschofenig if you agree, then please close this Issue.

issues.title: Adding the ability to convey Attestation Results in CSR
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body: Ned mentioned that the trusted path routing work requires the use of an attestation result.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Use case 2: RA interacts with the Verifier to obtain an Attestation Result and then includes the Attestation Result into the CSR to the CA

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Does this require structural changes to the EvidenceBundle?
Can you not pretend that in AttestationResult is an Evidence, and put it inside an EvidenceStatement?

Also, Use Case 2 is weird; normally the RA does not have the End Entity's private key, so the RA can't modify the CSR and re-sign it; so it would have to carry the Attestation Result next to the CSR. Unless the RA can "counter-sign" the CSR such that the CSR is no longer self-signed, but instead signed with an RA key, but that's getting weird.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
My first reaction is that this is getting a bit too scope-creepy; models where the Attester has interacted with the Verifier prior to creating the CSR is outside the scope of this diagram:

~~~
                              .-------------.
                              |             | Compare Evidence
                              |   Verifier  | against
                              |             | policy
                              '--------+----'
                                   ^   |
                          Evidence |   | Attestation
                                   |   | Result
                                   |   v
 .------------.               .----|----------.
 |            +-------------->|----'          | Compare Attestation
 |  Attester  |   Evidence    | Relying       | Result against
 |            |   in CSR      | Party (RA/CA) | policy
 '------------'               '---------------'
~~~

In other words, we chose to only do Background Check Model, and now it seems like we're also asking for Passport Model?

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
Mike Ounsworth ***@***.***> wrote:
    > My first reaction is that this is getting a bit too scope-creepy;
    > models where the Attester has interacted with the Verifier prior to
    > creating the CSR is outside the scope of this diagram:

I mostly agree.
I think that there are perhaps needs for the passport model for some HSMs,
but it should be out of scope for revision one.

comments.author: Akretsch
comments.body:
> Also, Use Case 2 is weird; normally the RA does not have the End Entity's private key, so the RA can't modify the CSR and re-sign it; so it would have to carry the Attestation Result next to the CSR. Unless the RA can "counter-sign" the CSR such that the CSR is no longer self-signed, but instead signed with an RA key, but that's getting weird.

If you use CRMF-centric enrollment protocols like CMP there would be a standard way to do, see https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9483.html#section-5.2.3.2

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Meeting with Hannes and Henk.
Decision: considering Passport Model, or the hybrid Passport-Background that Andreas proposes, are out-of-scope for this draft. We will probably need to add Attestation Results to CSR at some point, but that should be a new draft and new top-level CSR attribute / extension.

issues.title: OIDs for Evidence Formats need to be defined / listed somewhere
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
# The Problem

Developers implementing this specification will have a problem to find OIDs for the Evidence formats they are using. There is no repository that allows someone to just search for the values. Instead, developers need to search in the relevant specifications, which can be time consuming.

# Proposed Solution

The suggestion is to have IANA maintain a list of OID values for Evidence formats, a short description (name), and a reference to the specification where more details can be found, and a change controller. The change controller refers to the party that can update, or otherwise change the entry in the table. It does not list the controller of the OID itself.

Here is an example of how this table would look like.

```
 +-----------------------------------------------------------------------+
 | OID              | Name               | Reference | Change Controller |
 +------------------+--------------------+-----------+-------------------+
 | 2 23 133 5 4 10  | DICE Evidence      |   [1]     |  IESG             |
 | 2 23 133 5 4 9   | CMW                |   [1,2]   |  IESG             |
 +------------------+--------------------+-----------+-------------------+
```

References:

[1] "DICE Attestation Architecture", URL: https://trustedcomputinggroup.org/wp-content/uploads/DICE-Attestation-Architecture-Version-1.1-Revision-17_1August2023.pdf

[2] "RATS Conceptual Messages Wrapper", URL: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-rats-msg-wrap

issues.title: Add a hint to the RP about which verifier to call
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
Idea: add an OPTIONAL FQDN to the EvidenceStatement as a hint from the Attester to the RP about which Verifier to pass the evidence to. Related to the concept of "Audience".

This came up in discussion because some people were imagining that the EvidenceStatement.type OID would serve this purpose, but other people pointed out that this will not be the case when EvidenceStatement.type is, for example, "TCG_TPM" or "CMW".

There is a security question here about whether the not-yet-verified data should be allowed to tell the RP which code to call.

comments.author: Akretsch
comments.body: Maybe a GeneralName instead of a simple FQDN would be more ASN.1 style.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> There is a security question here about whether the not-yet-verified data should be allowed to tell the RP which code to call.

☝️

The RP must have a pre-established trust relationship with the verifier(s), surely it can't blindly follow a potentially malicious routing hint.

> This came up in discussion because some people were imagining that the EvidenceStatement.type OID would serve this purpose, but other people pointed out that this will not be the case when EvidenceStatement.type is, for example, "TCG_TPM" or "CMW".

Noting that CMW is a typed object so, in that sense, it's equivalent to EvidenceStatement: instead of EvidenceStatement.type OID the RP could use CMW's media type.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body:
Henk proposed to use the information related to the digital signature covering the Evidence to make a decision about where to route the Evidence to. I looked at one Evidence format, the PSA Attestation Token, and it does not carry information about the Verifier as part of the signature meta-data structure in its default form. (We only recently added the ability to carry certificate chains in the header as part of the x5chain header in a note).

Of course, this information could be included mandatorily but I don't think it is common in other Evidence formats either.

Even if we require this information to be included in every Evidence format, it means that the relying party needs to understands more about the encoding of the Evidence in order to make an assessment about where to route the Evidence.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I think an assumption that can be safely made is that the RP must be pre-configured with a list of trusted verifiers, each with its own network endpoints, API details, and authentication credentials.

A routing hint would then be a key that locates the verifier slot within such a list.

And that means that we'd need to agree on the "trusted verifiers configuration list" format in the first place.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: @hannestschofenig , @thomas-fossati please review PR #72 to see if it addresses this thread.

The 

```
EvidenceStatementSet EVIDENCE-STATEMENT ::= {
   ... -- None defined in this document --
}
```

is fine, but it would be illustrative to have an appendix with a worked example.

issues.title: Daniel Migault's editorial feedback
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
Hi, 

Please find my review of the document. Mostly hints except for freshness that I think we need to require or recommend a bit stronger. 

Yours, 
Daniel 

2 Intro:

"""
At the time of writing, several standard and several proprietary attestation technologies are in use. This specification thereby is intended to be as technology-agnostic as it is feasible with respect to implemented remote attestation technologies. Instead, it focuses on (1) the conveyance of Evidence via CSRs while making minimal assumptions about content or format of the transported Evidence and (2) the conveyance of sets of certificates used for validation of Evidence. The certificates typically contain one or more certification paths rooted in a device manufacture trust anchor and the leaf certificate being on the device in question; the latter is the Attestation Key that signs the Evidence statement. 
"""

I would probably add at the end of the paragraph: 
Evidences are carried in a Attribute designated as EvidenceStatements, certificates are carried in a CertificateAlternatives. EvidenceStatements and CertificateAlternatives are grouped into EvidenceBundles. 

"""
This document specifies two ATTRIBUTE/Attribute definitions. 
""

We do not really know if one is designated ATTRIBUTE while the other Attribute or if some call these two attributes ATTRIBUTES while other call them Attributes.
In my opinion, it would be clearer to name directly the Attributes CertificateAlternatives EvidenceStatements.
I would propose the following text:

This document specifies two Attributes. The first Attribute is CertificateAlternatives that may be used to carry a set of certificates or public keys that may be required to validate signed Evidence. The second Attribute is  EvidenceStatements that carries a structure that may be used to convey Evidence. These two Attributes combined into a 

"""
With these attributes, additional information about whether to issue a certificate and what information to populate into the certificate is available to an RA or CA.
"""

I am reading that the content of the evidence will determine the information of in the issued certificate. I THINK these Evidence will determine the issuance of the certificate if they are matching a policy and information provided is determined by policies. In my my opinion we should limit the scope to the policy.    
 
The scope of this document is, however, limited to the conveyance of Evidence within CSR. The exact format of the Evidence being conveyed is defined in various standard and proprietary specifications.

3 Architecture

<mglt> 
I tend to think we should indicate the CA/RA on the figure, potentially the HSM.
</mglt>


4.1 Intercation with an HSM

"""
As discussed in RFC 9334, different security and privacy aspects need to be considered. 
"""

I think we should say why. I would for example add:
As discussed in RFC 9334, different security and privacy aspects need to be considered to enforce trust in the Evidence.

"""
Finally, the keying material used by the Attester need to be protected against unauthorized access, and against signing arbitrary content that originated from outside the device.
"""
To me that seems to be the primary thing to be listed ;-)


Fig 2 I like OpenSSL and I think it should remain but probably as an example. 

"""
 the generates and embeds Evidence and the corresponding certificate chains when constructing the CSR.
"""

I suspect "HSM" is missing I propose:
The HSM generates and embeds....

Fig 2: I think HSM here is composed of the attestation environment and the service. getEvidence is addressed to the platform sign to the service. I am wondering if we should split these two. Note that I see the service as "Software" so maybe I am biassed.  


"""
Externally-generated CSRs may require extra round-trips of communication between the CSR generator and the attesting environment, first to obtain the necessary evidence statements about the subject key, and then to use the subject key to sign the CSR. For example, consider a CSR generated by a popular crypto library about a subject key stored on a PKCS#11 [PKCS11] device. 
"""
Should we replace "evidence statements" by Evidence ? I do not think that popular is necessary, mentioning "(like OpenSSL): might be helpful. I know it used to be on the figure.    
4.2. Implementation Strategies

Fig 3 :  the meaning of 0,n are  bit enigmatic to me. In particular I am wondering if inverting 0 and n would change the meaning. I interpret it as meaning between 0 - n. If that is the case, the text mentions one to many, so maybe that needs some clarifications.


Maybe we could mention  that CertificateAlternatives represents various format of certificates I propose to complement the last sentence of the paragraph to:
Each EvidenceBundle contains one or multiple EvidenceStatement structures as well as one or many CertificateAlternatives which enable to carry various format of certificates. 

 
"""
Single Attester, which only distributes Evidence without any certificate chains, i.e. the Verifier is assumed to be in possession of the certificate chain already or there is no certificate chain.  
"""
I think what the last sentence is saying is the say the statements are not signed. 
If so, "or there is no certificate chain." should be replaced by "or statements ar enot signed."

 
"""
It may be possible that there is an overlap in the certificate chains transmitted by the different Attesters. 
"""
I think we can be more specific and say: 
This may result in certificates being duplicated across multiple EvidenceBundles.

Implementation strategies to order certificates are only useful if they can be used, so I suspect we should provide some requirements such as the strategies described here MUST be supported and Certificates MUST be ordered from leaf to top. We should also  specify whether the root CA needs to be placed probably a SHOULD NOT or MUST NOT. A verifier SHOULD NOT make any assumption.... 


5.2 Evidence Attribute and Extension

"""
The hint is intended for an Attester to indicate to the Relying Party which Verifier should be invoked to parse this statement. 
"""
We need to specify that RP will designate later the Relaying party. I propose to change "Relying Party" to "Relying Party (RP)"

"""
In many cases, the type OID will already uniquely indicate which Verifier to invoke, but in some cases it may still be ambiguous, or the type may indicate another layer of conceptual message wrapping in which case it is helpful to the RP to bring this hint outside of the statement. 
"""
I think we need to explicitly mention why the OID will indicate the Verifier. I suspect the reasoning is that OID will be vendor specific and Verifier will be vendor specific as well. I expect that verifier will be also configured by the client and as such who will send the CSR but such authentication will be made outside the scope of the CSR.
I understand that hint indicates the Verifier. Do we expect the hint to be something like a FQDN ? 
One thing one need to consider is that I have the impression the hint cannot be trusted unless the CSR is generated by the attesting environment.  If that is correct, we probably need to be cautious regarding that hint and mention it in the security considerations. 


I do not clearly see what id-ata represents. I have the impression this is the arc under which all Evidence Statement will be registered. id-ata.1, id-ata.2, ... will represent evidence statements. This specific evidence statements are represented by the EvidenceStatementSet structure.

I am reading that id-aa-evidenceStatement represents EvidenceBundles. If so I am wondering why do not we call it id-aa-evidenceBundles.


The following text is quite obscure to me:
"""
We are leaving the SEQUENCE OF EvidenceBundle since it is in general more flexible than relying on the containing structure to handle multiplicity and allows for this structure to be re-used in the future in other PKIX protocol contexts.
"""

7: Security Consideration

"""
A PKCS#10 or CRMF Certification Request message consists of a distinguished name, a public key, and optionally a set of attributes, collectively signed by the entity requesting certification. 
"""
Well with DN being the certificate Subject I think it can be empty. I woudl propose to replace distinguished name by an identity or identifier. 

"""
The private key used to sign the CSR MUST be different from the Attesting Key utilized to sign Evidence about the Target Environment. 
"""

This seems correct - at least in general -, but I am questioning we never never never have a case where a root CA requests a CSR... 

"""
Key separation is an important principle in cryptography and also applies to this specification with regards to the Attestation Key and the CSR signing key.
"""

I do not really understand the sentence, CSR the key is signing the CSR prove the ownership of the key for which a certificate is issued. Evidences are signed to authenticate thetrust of the evidences. I guess I am missing something here.  


"""
For example, one implementation may perform a software measurement of the CSR library along with the crypto library implementation that has access to the keying material.
"""
I am reading software measurement as the CSR being a target environment.  
If the CSR library is outside the attesting environment, it is unclear to me how it can be attested unless we are in a multi attester use case. 


"""
None of these things are practical when interacting with Hardware Security Modules (HSM).
"""
I think I disagree here and we need to have freshness or at least some lifetime for Evidences. TLS or ACME  are ways to provide a nonce that needs to be considered during the attestation. We should strongly recommend to implement freshness. It is correct that freshness can be implemented in various ways, including a simple serial number. The threat model seems simple, the key is generated on a HSM, the crypto becomes weak, I can generate the key on my raspberry pie, the CSR can be used for that key - while all certificate have expired. CSR are not necessarily encrypted.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
This comment is better addressed by @hannestschofenig or @henkbirkholz who is more familiar with the security and privacy considerations of RATS.

> """
As discussed in RFC 9334, different security and privacy aspects need to be considered.
"""

>I think we should say why. I would for example add:
As discussed in RFC 9334, different security and privacy aspects need to be considered to enforce trust in the Evidence.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
7.1
This sentence is wrong:

> None of these things are practical when interacting with Hardware Security Modules (HSM).

This could use a strong statement that freshness MAY be contained inside the embedded Evidence, or it may be carried in the certificate management protocol that is carrying this CSR, but freshness is out-of-scope for the CSR itself, which is the focus of this document.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
@Daniel Migault

> Implementation strategies to order certificates are only useful if they can be used, so I suspect we should provide some requirements such as the strategies described here MUST be supported and Certificates MUST be ordered from leaf to top. We should also  specify whether the root CA needs to be placed probably a SHOULD NOT or MUST NOT. A verifier SHOULD NOT make any assumption.... 

I vote against this. This section is meant to be examples / informative. I think that if we try to make this section normative, then we will get into trouble.

In general, we are providing containers and want to leave room for an Attester and Verifier from the same vendor to use these structures however they want.

In particular, if we say anything about mandatory certificate order, then we make it hard for cases where we want to include multiple cert chains, or multiple partial cert chains in a single EvidenceBundle. We decided at a meeting that things like P12 files already require certificate parsing clients to be able to handle bags of certificates in arbitrary order that may contain extra certs not needed for a specific Leaf -> CA path, so it is fair to also expect this of Verifiers. If a given vendor's Verifier cannot do this, then they should construct their Evidence accordingly, but I do not think that the specification should arbitrarily restrict those of us with proper certificate path building logic :)

Similar reasoning for whether the Root should be placed or not. For example, in complex cross-certified or bridged PKIs it is possible that a self-signed root certificate is not in your trust store, but it is cross-signed as a subordinate of a root that is. So in that case the Attester would need to include the root cert in the EvidenceBundle.

I think that making any restrictions here on what may be in the certificate list will make it impossible to transmit certain complex PKIs, only for the benefit of simple PKIs that do not implement 5280 path-building properly :)

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
On Daniel's final point about freshness.

I think we discussed this during the meeting on 2024-01-29.

This draft is just an envelope; it is just a carrier for existing Evidence formats. We have tried to say, in general terms, that freshness is good, but that it may not always be possible, and regardless, it is outside the scope of this draft.

I am open to alternate wording, if you want to propose something.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: All merged in #81

issues.title: GeneralName is too broad for EvidenceHint
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
Russ suggested that GeneralName is too broad and complicated.

For reference, here is the definition of GeneralName:

~~~
   GeneralName ::= CHOICE {
        otherName                   [0]  INSTANCE OF OTHER-NAME,
        rfc822Name                  [1]  IA5String,
        dNSName                     [2]  IA5String,
        x400Address                 [3]  ORAddress,
        directoryName               [4]  Name,
        ediPartyName                [5]  EDIPartyName,
        uniformResourceIdentifier   [6]  IA5String,
        iPAddress                   [7]  OCTET STRING,
        registeredID                [8]  OBJECT IDENTIFIER
   }
~~~

We could strip that down to something like:
~~~
   EvidenceHint ::= CHOICE {
        rfc822Name [0] IA5String,
        dNSName [1] IA5String,
        uri [2] IA5String,
        text [3] UTF8String }
~~~

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Your suggestion is good for me.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Not entirely sure about completeness or appropriateness, but if that satisfies Russ' requirements, I am okay.

issues.title: Introduction: Clarifying Assumptions
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
Ned & Monty suggest to provide further text to explain what the assumptions for creating an interoperable implementation are. 

Questions to be answered, for example, are: 

- What other specifications do need to be read/implemented when the Verifier is not co-located with the RA/CA?
- How is the Attestation Result content?
- What is conveyed in the Certificate about the attestation verification?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
I think my responses here are:

> What other specifications do need to be read/implemented when the Verifier is not co-located with the RA/CA?
> How is the Attestation Result content?

What API the Verifier presents to the RA/CA is out of scope for this CSR wire-format document.

> What is conveyed in the Certificate about the attestation verification?

The contents of issued certificates are out of scope for this CSR wire-format document.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> I think my responses here are:
> 
> > What other specifications do need to be read/implemented when the Verifier is not co-located with the RA/CA?
> > How is the Attestation Result content?
> 
> What API the Verifier presents to the RA/CA is out of scope for this CSR wire-format document.

I agree.  It would however, be good if anyone who has a protocol that they intend to use confirms that they have all the bits they need.  That needn't be a blocker.

> > What is conveyed in the Certificate about the attestation verification?
> 
> The contents of issued certificates are out of scope for this CSR wire-format document.

I agree that this is true.  Is there any CABFORUM view on this?  Is there a policy OID that they would telling CAs to include if they comply, and can that document be informatively cited as motivation for this work?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
@mcr 

> Is there any CABFORUM view on this? Is there a policy OID that they would telling CAs to include if they comply, and can that document be informatively cited as motivation for this work?

I think the prevailing attitude is that the Code Signing BRs require that the CA verify that the subscriber's keys are in hardware. How the CA does that is up to the CA with Attestation being one of the acceptable methods; various signed letters and screenshots of admin consoles being another. So IF (Code_Signing); THEN hardware check must have been done.

We already had this text buried down in the Security Considerations.

> The Code-Signing Baseline Requirements [CSBR] document is an example of such a policy that has been published by the CA Browser Forum and specifies certain properties, such as non-exportability, which must be enabled for storing publicly-trusted code-signing keys. Other policies influence

I'll strengthen that to include a section reference and copy it up to the Intro.

> The Code-Signing Baseline Requirements [[CSBR](https://lamps-wg.github.io/csr-attestation/draft-ietf-lamps-csr-attestation.html#CSBR)] document, **specifically section 6.2.7.3 Private key storage for Signing Services**, is an example of such a policy that has been published by the CA Browser Forum and specifies certain properties, such as non-exportability, which must be enabled for storing publicly-trusted code-signing keys. Other policies influence

issues.title: Typo's and a minor question
issues.author: dieterbong
issues.body:
When reviewing draft-ietf-lamps-csr-attestation-02 I noticed the following typo's:
section 4.3: ""TypedCert" is an ASN.1 construct that has the **charateristics** ..." 
section 6.1: "... certificate enrollments are often **asyncronous**, ..." 
section 8.1: "... **digitially** signed with ..." 
top of page 21: "...the shown Evidence, provides..." I would not put a comma here but I let a native speaker decide

And a question:
[I-D.tschofenig-rats-psa-token] refers to version 13 of this draft, but there is already a version 20. Should the csr-attestation draft point to version 20? Or to the latest version of rats-psa-token when finalizing the csr attestation draft?

Best regards,
Dieter

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Thank you @dieterbong for catching the typos.

For the question:
In the source of the markdown, no version is referenced, so it must have been that -13 was current the last time we did a build and pushed to datatracker. If I build my local copy today then it references -20. 

~~~
informative:
  RFC7030:
  I-D.tschofenig-rats-psa-token:
~~~

Regardless, all this gets cleaned up in editor's queue anyway; id-tschofenig-rats-psa-token will need to be published and assigned an RFC number before it can be referenced by another RFC; the RFC editor takes care of publishing things in the correct order so that the cross-references work out cleanly.

issues.title: Comments from MSJ
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
1) "Lead Attester" is not defined anywhere, but used in multiple places.   A paragraph on that role and its responsibilities appears to be necessary.
2) Section 4.2 needs subsections for each of the cases.   At least one diagram has both a caption and free floating identifiers (e.g. "Implementation strategy 4b" vs "Figure 7....") that are indistinguishable from body text. There needs to be a way to differentiate between body text and a title for the various cases and objects.     So a) split Figure 7 into two different figures, b) have a section on "Case 4" with subsections on "Implementation Strategy 4a" and "Implementation Strategy 4b" with the appropriate figures from Figure 7 within the section boundaries.  This is mostly editorial, but needs cleanup for figuring out which text paragraph belongs with which diagram.
4.2 - How to encode
4.2.1 - Case 1 - Single Evidence Bundle
4.2.2 - Case 2 - Single Evidence Bundle with Certificates
4.2.3 - Case 3 - Multiple Evidence Bundles each with complete Paths
4.2.4 - Case 4 - Multiple Evidence Bundles with Certificate Transmission Optimization
4.2.4.1 - Strategy 4a
4.2.4.2 - Strategy 4b.

3) Can Case 1 (where the validator is thought to know some of Case 1's certificates) be encoded as part of Case 4?  I.e., is it legal to have an EvidenceBundle with no certificates as part of any of Case 4?  Or for that matter Case 3?  
4) What knowledge must a "Leader Attester" have to select between each of the cases for encoding?   I.e., pre-configured?, some policy object they got?  Specific guidance from each of the possible validators each wanting the same data formatted in a specific way to make their lives easier?
5) Must a validator that can handle Case 3, must also be able to go looking for certs in other bundles if the chain for a given bundle can't be built for validation?  Or must that be treated as a non-validation error by the validator?
6) May a 4B output contain multiple EvidenceBundles each looking like 4B but with a partially disjoint set of certificates?  The description for 4b looks more like case 3 than a special case of 4.
7) May you mix and match the various cases?  And must a Validator be required to riffle through all the various bundles to find the right mix of certificates to validate a given evidence statement?
Text needs to be written to cover answers for each of these I believe.
8) Evidence Hint appears to be a way to convey type data that's otherwise buried inside of an Evidence Object of identical top-level types.  This seems to be laziness to not require different OIDs for different pseudo-wrapped and typed evidence statements from DICE ConceptualMessageWrapper (the example, but also handwaving other possibilities).  Recommend elimination of this and putting the onus on the post-processing software to do the differentiation if the proponents of these types of objects don't want to request multiple OIDs.  I don't find the arguments for inclusion convincing.  
9) The TPM example needs work, A2.3
9a)  
The structure here needs to be de-OCTET STRING'd.
E.g. 
TpmV2Attest ::= OCTET STRING -- This is formatted as the encoding of <tpmv2 structures, TPMS_ATTEST>.  
                                                        -- This may be any of the valid attestation structures. For a signature over a public key, only a hash of related public key data is included under the signature.
Tpm2InternalSig ::= OCTET STRING -- This is formatted as the encoding of <tpmv2 structures TPMT_SIGNATURE>.  This structure includes the type of signature as well as the actual signature bytes/bits 
Tpm2Public ::= OCTET STRING -- This is formatted as <tpmv2 structures TPMT_PUBLIC>.  This structure includes the type of key as well as the key bytes.  This is the key being signed.

Tcg-csr-certify ::= SEQUENCE {
   tpmSAttest ::= TpmV2Attest,
   tpmSignature :: = Tpm2InternalSig, -- This is the signature returned by a call to TPM2_Certify over the tpmSAttest object.
   tpmTPublic ::= Tpm2Public OPTIONAL -- This is REQUIRED if the attestation is over a public key  (e.g. if TPMS_ATTEST.type == ???) as it's the only way to map from the key being attested to the attestation.
}
9b) tcg-kp-AIKCertificateField????   This is an extended key purpose OID.  There is no field that contains the AIK certificate.  
9c) A2.5.1 - the TPMU_ATTEST field is a Union identified by .type.  The TPMS_CERTIFY_INFO is union value of what's certified for a public key
9d) If you've got TPMU_ATTEST, you need to explain how to get from Tpm2Public (TPMT_PUBLIC) to the value of the attested field.
9e) Sample CSR - how does the lead attester know what software is installed on the validator's side (e.g. package tpmverifier.example.com)?   This implies there needs to be a registry mapping "hints" to something global.  In any event, if you have the OID and you have the structure definitions pointed to that OID, then the Hint is extraneous.  If the validator has multiple ways of resolving a TPMv2 attestation, they're doing it wrong.  Repeat my recommendation to remove hints.
10) Should additional CMS error codes be added for this new extension?  E.g. RFC5272, section 6.1.1 - ExtendedFailInfo.  I don't see how CMCStatus or CMCFailInfo can be extended to cover the possible chaining errors and evidence/validator mismatches.  Ditto for CMP?
Later, Mike

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> 1. "Lead Attester" is not defined anywhere,

9334 quasi defines and uses it in examples. The use here is intended to align with 9334 use. Is that not the case / should this reference 9334?

>4. ... "Leader Attester"

I assume this is a typo.

> 8. Evidence Hint appears to be a way to convey type data that's otherwise buried inside of an Evidence Object

The PR #125 defines the `type` and `hint` objects. The type is an OID from the table of OIDs further in the I-D. e.g.: type: OBJECT IDENTIFIER tcg-dice-TcbInfo (2.23.133.5.4.1)
Hint is a quasi URI that describes the same object e.g. "DiceTcbInfo.example.com" 

Possibly, the CSR example should be defined to the same level of detail as the DiceTcbInfo example. Then type would be `type: OBJECT IDENTIFIER tcg-dice-DiceConceptualMessageWrapper (2.23.133.5.4.9)` and hint would be `"DiceConceptualMessageWrapper.example.com"`.

Otherwise, the feedback is unclear about what `laziness` means. Possibly, `type` is sufficient and `hint` has no value?

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
> I can't see how AR could be inserted by the Verifier into the CSR. If the verifier (operated by the HSM manufacturer, or their representative) needs to communicate things other than pass/fail with the RP (the CA), then they need a different protocol.

I expect we'll see a lot of "Pass/Fail for a given evidence verification profile" (or whatever the right RATS term is for that). Like "Does this CSR indicate compliance with CA/B BRs?", or "Did this CSR come from TPM-backed CAPI on a fully-patched Windows?". Or maybe even, the CA hands the verifier a list of evidence verification profiles (maybe each with its own trust store), and the Verifier hands back a list of profiles that this CSR complies with, the CA then smacks the corresponding OIDs on the cert.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> I expect we'll see a lot of "Pass/Fail for a given evidence verification profile" (or whatever the right RATS term is for that). Like "Does this CSR indicate compliance with CA/B BRs?", or "Did this CSR come from TPM-backed CAPI on a fully-patched Windows?". Or maybe even, the CA hands the verifier a list of evidence verification profiles (maybe each with its own trust store), and the Verifier hands back a list of profiles that this CSR complies with, the CA then smacks the corresponding OIDs on the cert.

Sure, but none of those messages can go INTO the CSR. Because it's signed by the Attester, and the Verifier can't modify that.
RATS does not define a protocol between RP and Verifier: we have to pick one or design one.
Your initial proposal that it's a proprietary popen("|hsm-manufacturer-module") is probably a good one for now.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Where does the terminology conflict with  RFC 9334 and RFC 4949 terminology?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
A few prominent examples:

* Examples of major conflicts
    * w.r.t. RFC 9334, `This evidence is to be verified by a relying party`: "verified" means nothing in the RATS scope and Evidence is never appraised by a Relying Party - only by Verifiers
    * w.r.t. RFC 4949, `certificate chains` is a term deprecated at least for 15 years and `certification path` should be used.
* Examples of minor conflicts
    * `evidence signed by certificate chains` This makes no sense. An Attester signes Evidence and it probably should sign with appropriate key material that is endorsed via certification paths
    * to stay in sync with RFC 9334 (colloquial) language, it is preferable to write that RATS conceptual messages are `conveyed` and not `carried`

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body:
I created two PRs to address the issues you have raised above instead of re-writing the text altogether. 

Three comments:

* Certificate chains is not a depreciated term. It depends what you want to say. 
* The terms "convey" and "carry" (or "transport") mean the same thing.
* The term "appraise" is something that aims to give the impression that there is something magic going on while in reality you are just comparing the provided data against some reference values. "Verification" is more natural.

pulls.body: This PR addresses issues #59 and #60.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Comments:

1.
In the aasvg, you have "1..n EvidenceBundle", "0..n CertificateAlternatives", and "1..n EvidenceStatement".
I agree that's how I also imagine this being user,d but technically they are all declared as SEQUENCE, so are all 0..n. 
For example, if your Evidence is already an X.509 certificate then you could conceivably put that in the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives and leave the SEQUENCE OF EvidenceStatement empty. I'm not sure that's a good idea, but it is allowed under the current definitions.


2.
I think we should add a usecase that deals with Endorsements. This is related to #63. 
Possibly just modify the wording of #3 to "... multiple Attesters or Endorsers", and "... Evidence or Endorsement statements".


3.
I think there are actually two valid ways of addressing #4: the one you describe where a Verifier has to look across EvidenceBundles in order to find the complete cert chains that it needs, or merging all of those into a single EvidenceBundle with a single de-duplicated SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives; that would look like:

```
 +-------------------------+
 |  EvidenceBundle         |
 +-------------------------+
 | EvidenceStatements {     |
 |   EvidenceStatement (1)  |
 |   ...                     |
 |  EvidenceStatement (n)  |
 | }                         |
 | CertificateAlternatives { |
 |  EndEntity (1)          |
 |  ...                     |
 |  EndEntity (n)            |
 | <remainder of           |
 |     certificate chain >     |
 | }                   |
 +-------------------------+
```

We could call what you wrote 4a, and this 4b. 4a helps the verifier by providing 1-to-1 mapping between EvidenceStatements and the EndEntity certificate to verify it, but makes the Relying Party implementation more complicated, for example by needing to re-assemble complete certificate chains across EvidenceBundles if the Verifier needs to be invoked separately for each EvidenceStatement.
Whereas 4b means that each EvidenceBundle is self-contained and any EvidenceStatement can be verified using only the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives in its bundle, but Verifiers will have to do proper certificate path building since the SEQUENCE OF CertificateAlternatives is now a cert bag and not a cert chain.
Pros and Cons to both.

```suggestion
~~~ aasvg
```

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: I don't have push permissions on Monty's fork, so I am merging into a side branch, I'll do a few fixes, then merge into main.

Hello! 👋🏻 Great write-up! I was reading through and got a bit confused by this line, specifically by `the EK is used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key`. My understanding was that the EK is used to assure a 3rd party (in this case the Privacy CA / Attestation CA) that the AK is in the same TPM as the EK, not for the CA to issue the AK. Am I getting this wrong?

I think we are saying the same thing. The Attestation CA is just a special CA that uses the TPM protocols (including the EK) to prove the AK is in the same TPM (and has the expected attributes). The Attestation CA then issues a certificate for the AK. Since the AK is a signing key (the EK is a decryption key so the protocol is a bit awkward and non-standard - again, this is one of the reasons we use the term Attestation CA because it acts as a non-standard CA) it is easier to get a signed statement about the properties of a "user key". Defining that signed statement is the point of this effort.
Agree, but I don't see how that maps to `used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key` - perhaps `used by an Attestation CA to create an Attestation Key certificate` is clearer?

Ha, you are correct. Authors sometimes miss the subtitle wording and when I read ...create and Attestation Key... I meant what you said. A subtle but very important difference. Thanks for pointing this out.

pulls.title: Addressing Carl's review
pulls.author: ounsworth
pulls.body:
Closes #126 

INCOMPLETE -- DO NOT MERGE YET
I am up to the beginning of Section 5.3 in Carl's feedback
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/UVQ0yXAEqsm9snJIOcelFQoYyEA/


Responses to Carl:
---

> "Residency" doesn't seem quite right since it misses the non-exportability requirement that is usually a goal. Maybe steal some verbiage from the CAB Forum guidelines and say: "Regulatory bodies are beginning to require proof that keys are generated in a non‐exportable way using a suitable Hardware Crypto Module."

I am going to leave this one as-is. I think that "proof of hardware residency" is not incorrect, and is made more precise in the following sentence, including the direct quote from the CA/B CSBRs.



> The last paragraph leaves open the possibility of having multiple instantiations of attr-evidence or ext-evidence but does not mention the fact that the values field in Attribute can contain multiple values. Do we really need three ways to convey multiple evidence bundles, i.e., via EvidenceBundles, via multiple attributes, via multiple attribute values? Is there any reason to not just limit this to one attribute/extension, one value within attribute and let EvidenceBundles handle collections?


Yes, good point.
I have attempted to strengthen this, but I would love review of the new paragraph. Have I correctly understood and referenced the AttributeSet and ExtensionSet stuff from RFC5912? Is there a better way to enforce this through the ASN.1 definitions?
